questions.question_text: Which component of the Cisco Cyber Threat Defense solution provides user and flow context analysis?

discussion.content: Stealthwatch collects telemetry from every part of the network and applies advanced security analytics to the data. It creates a baseline of normal web and network activity for a network host, and applies context-aware analysis to automatically detect anomalous behaviors.
The given solution is correct

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Stealthwatch is now a deprecated name, as the 1.1 OCG points out it is now called Cisco Secure Network Analytics.
"Cisco Secure Network Analytics, formerly Stealthwatch Enterprise, is a collector and aggregator of network telemetry data..."
Similarly, Stealthwatch Cloud is now Cisco Secure Cloud Analytics.
However, past experience has shown that questions like this WILL still be asked using the old terms, so knowing the answer is B here is still useful.

Of course B is right 
from OCG

Cisco Stealthwatch is a collector and aggregator of network telemetry data that performs
network security analysis and monitoring to automatically detect threats that manage to
infiltrate a network as well as the ones that originate from within a network.

Selected Answer: B
Given answer is correct.

https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/security/network_security/ctd/ctd2-0/design_guides/ctd_2-0_cvd_guide_jul15.pdf

Page 4.

questions.question_text: Which control plane protocol is used between Cisco SD-WAN routers and vSmart controllers?

discussion.content: OMP overlay management protocol is used in sd-wan its a lot like IP-Sec tunnels

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
OMP is correct

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
D is wrong. BGP can't be used
C is wrong. UDP can't be used. 
A is wrong. TCP can't be used. 
Only reasonable option is B

Selected Answer: B
Cisco vSmart controllers facilitate fabric discovery by running the Overlay Management Protocol (OMP) between each other and between Cisco vSmart and the Cisco WAN Edge routers. Cisco WAN Edge routers and Cisco vSmart controllers act as a distribution system for the pertinent information required to establish the data plane connectivity directly between the Cisco WAN Edge routers. This information includes service-side (LAN) reachability, transport-side IP addressing, IPsec encryption keys, site identifiers, and so on.

Selected Answer: B
thats correct, OMP (Overlay Management Protocol)
Regards!

Selected Answer: B
B

The Viptela Overlay Management Protocol (OMP) establishes and maintains the Viptela control plane.

OMP is enabled by default on all vEdge routers, vManage NMSs, and vSmart controllers, so there is no need to explicitly configure or enable OMP. OMP must be operational for the Viptela overlay network to function. If you disable it, you disable the overlay network.

Reference:
https://sdwan-docs.cisco.com/Product_Documentation/vManage_Help/Release_18.3/Configuration/Templates/OMP#:~:text=The%20Viptela%20Overlay,the%20overlay%20network.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
Overlay management Protocol used as the control plane protocol for SDWAN

Selected Answer: B
Voting. provided answer is correct.
Provided answer is correct

questions.question_text:
An engineer must protect their company against ransomware attacks.
Which solution allows the engineer to block the execution stage and prevent file encryption?

discussion.content: AMP with MAP :)

B is correct:
https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/products/collateral/security/amp-for-endpoints/white-paper-c11-740980.pdf
Malicious Activity Protection provides run-time detection and blocking of abnormal behavior of a running program on the endpoint (for example,behaviors associated with ransomware).

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

See Malicious activity protection at
 https://www.cisco-parts.ru/upload/iblock/632/cisco-advanced-malware-protection.pdf

choices.C: Use Cisco Firepower with Intrusion Policy and snort rules blocking SMB exploitation.
choices.A: Use Cisco Firepower and block traffic to TOR networks.
choices.B: Use Cisco AMP deployment with the Malicious Activity Protection engine enabled.
choices.D: Use Cisco AMP deployment with the Exploit Prevention engine enabled.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

An engineer must deny Telnet traffic from the loopback interface of router R3 to the loopback interface of router R2 during the weekend hours. All other traffic between the loopback interfaces of routers R3 and R2 must be allowed at all times.
Which command set accomplishes this task?

comments.content: Men i keep forgetting that i need to work on that, thanks

discussion.content:
B
Access lists that are applied to interfaces do not filter traffic that originates from that router!

A - wrong because outbound list won't block telnet from same router, AND it has the time-range on the permit statement.
B- correct!
C- wrong because it has no deny statement
D- wrong because it includes Friday

Selected Answer: A
R3(config)#time-range WEEKEND
R3(config-time-range)#periodic Saturday Sunday 00:00 to 23:59

R3(config)#access-list 150 deny tcp host 10.3.3.3 host 10.2.2.2 eq 23 time-range WEEKEND
R3(config)#access-list 150 permit ip any any

R3(config)#interface G0/1
R3(config-if)#ip access-group 150 out # we filter trafic as close to the source as possible with extended ACLs
Shouldn't the ACL be applied outbound on R1 Gi0/1 interface?

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
even if the solution is not the best practice, cause the access-list is recommended to be applied on the R3 interface outbound.

comments.content: Sorry, I misread, D is using the wrong days entirely. Friday isn't part of weekend period.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B.
A and C are easily discarded with the fact that ACLs are not processed by the router that originates the traffic.
D is using a wrong time range, I think that if you're going to define the day individually the syntax should be something like this:

time-range TEST
 periodic Saturday 00:00 to Sunday 23:59

but the keyword "weekend" covers this day range.

Selected Answer: B
ACL cannot block traffic originates from the router were is applicatted
Regards

comments.content:
cisco_R3(config-ext-nacl)#do s access-l | b 266
Extended IP access list q_266
 10 deny tcp any any eq www time-range q_277 (inactive)
 20 permit tcp any any range 22 443

cisco_R3(config-ext-nacl)#do s runn | s access-l
...
ip access-list extended q_266
 deny tcp any any eq www time-range q_277
 permit tcp any any range 22 443

cisco_R3#show time-range
time-range entry: q_277 (inactive)
 periodic weekend 0:00 to 23:59
 used in: IP ACL entry
cisco_R3#

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
cisco_R3(config)#time-range q_277
cisco_R3(config-time-range)#periodic ?
 Friday Friday
 Monday Monday
 Saturday Saturday
 Sunday Sunday
 Thursday Thursday
 Tuesday Tuesday
 Wednesday Wednesday
 daily Every day of the week
 weekdays Monday thru Friday
 weekend Saturday and Sunday

cisco_R3(config-time-range)#periodic weekend ?
 hh:mm Starting time

cisco_R3(config-time-range)#periodic weekend 00:00 ?
 to ending day and time

cisco_R3(config-time-range)#periodic weekend 00:00 to ?
 hh:mm Ending time - stays valid until beginning of next minute

cisco_R3(config-time-range)#periodic weekend 00:00 to 23:59

Selected Answer: B
Both A and B will block the telnet traffic during the weekend. But only B will allow the rest of the traffic during the the rest of the days. Answer is B.
This question is still asked. Passed today.

C. 
RouterR3(config)#time-range WEEKEND 
RouterR3(config-time-range)#periodic weekend 00:00 to 23:59 
RouterR3(config)#access-list 150 permit tcp host 10.3.3.3 host 10.2.2.2 eq 23 time-range WEEKEND 
RouterR3(config)#access-list 150 permit ip any any time-range WEEKEND 
RouterR3(config)#interface G0/1 
RouterR3(config-if)#ip access-group 150 out
D. 
RouterR1(config)#time-range WEEKEND 
RouterR1(config-time-range)#periodic Friday Sunday 00:00 to 00:00 
RouterR1(config)#access-list 150 deny tcp host 10.3.3.3 host 10.2.2.2 eq 23 time-range WEEKEND 
RouterR1(config)#access-list 150 permit ip any any 
RouterR1(config)#interface G0/1 
RouterR1(config-if)#ip access-group 150 in

comments.content: Yes, B is right, the outbound access list can't block traffic from the control plane (CLI).
Actually, there is a periodic weekend... but... Ill check it again.

discussion.content: A is the right answer. there is no "periodic weekend" command.

choices.B: R1(config)#time-range WEEKEND R1(config-time-range)#periodic weekend 00:00 to 23:59 R1(config)#access-list 150 deny tcp host 10.3.3.3 host 10.2.2.2 eq 23 time-range WEEKEND R1(config)#access-list 150 permit ip any any R1(config)#interface G0/1 R1(config-if)#ip access-group 150 in
choices.D: R1(config)#time-range WEEKEND R1(config-time-range)#periodic Friday Sunday 00:00 to 00:00 R1(config)#access-list 150 deny tcp host 10.3.3.3 host 10.2.2.2 eq 23 time-range WEEKEND R1(config)#access-list 150 permit ip any any R1(config)#interface G0/1 R1(config-if)#ip access-group 150 in
choices.C: R3(config)#time-range WEEKEND R3(config-time-range)#periodic weekend 00:00 to 23:59 R3(config)#access-list 150 permit tcp host 10.3.3.3 host 10.2.2.2 eq 23 time-range WEEKEND R3(config)#access-list 150 permit ip any any time-range WEEKEND R3(config)#interface G0/1 R3(config-if)#ip access-group 150 out
choices.A: R3(config)#time-range WEEKEND R3(config-time-range)#periodic Saturday Sunday 00:00 to 23:59 R3(config)#access-list 150 deny tcp host 10.3.3.3 host 10.2.2.2 eq 23 time-range WEEKEND R3(config)#access-list 150 permit ip any any time-range WEEKEND R3(config)#interface G0/1 R3(config-if)#ip access-group 150 out

discussion.content: The correct answer is C...
Just noticed the G0/0 is towards the web server NOT the PC...Then is permit host 192.168.0.5 eq 8080 host 172.16.0.2

comments.content: Agreed. Its the traffic coming back from the initial connection. C is correct.
Same here, looks like the G0/0 is the interface facing the PC but no, it is facing the SERVER, so the answer is C :)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Option A would have been correct if we were filtering the outbound traffic exiting port G 0/0.
Option B is incorrect because the web server is using port 8080, not PC1. PC1 will randomly choose a source port from the ephemeral range: 49152 and 65535. 
Option D is incorrect because we need to filter traffic coming from the web server on port 8080 ("lt 8080" will allow TCP connections coming from the server with a source port less than 8080).

Selected Answer: C
The correct answer is C...

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

the question states "Inbound direction"
which means that if the PC tried to connect to the server, the server should have the ability to reply. so in reality you should have 2 access-lists one for traffic from PC1 to the server and another one for traffic from the server to PC1.
the question is asking you in a tricky way about the traffic from the server to the PC1 just by stating "Inbound"
They could have placed the port label on the right side. I thought it was for the cable facing the PC...

Selected Answer: C
Be aware that G0/0 port is the one connected to the server.
The catch here is that the ACE doesn't filter any ingress traffic from PC-1. It filters the inbound traffic from the webserver. So naturally, you need to permit the ingress traffic sourced at the web server.

The correct answer is C.

Since the rule is to be applied Inbound to SW2 Gi0/0, we need to invoke the rule guiding Source Port and Destination Port.

<protocol> <source IP/source network> <source port> <destination IP/destination network> <destination port>

Therefore, 

permit tcp host 192.168.0.5 eq 8080 host 172.16.0.2

comments.content:
lol, its a bit tricky 
first thing i noticed was where int is facing

discussion.content: i hope whoever made this exhibit no longer works in cisco.

Answer is C.
The ACL is put on the interface facing the web server that receives a request on port 8080 ---> the answer has source port 8080 and is the web-server as the direction of the ACL is input (from outside to the router).

the obvious quick answer choice for most commonly seen deployments would be answer A. but since that is the only one with 172 as the source, there must be some trick going on! So after looking again, C it is, but this is not a typical ACL found almost anywhere and on a switch for that matter. dumb question for real life. also remember that ports can be applied to both source and dest, which means the port will follow each one. this rules out B as syntactically incorrect.

Selected Answer: C
This question would be correct if the equipment would be a router not a switch. In that case C is correct.

comments.content: If your ACL is in an outbound direction on the G0/0 A would be fine, but in this case the ACL is in a inbound direction meaning that it will be looking at traffic from the server to the PC

Answer is either A or C. Depending on the placement of the g0/0 label. But in normal situtation the ACL should be placed as closed as possible to the source of the traffic you want to control to avoid unecessary resource usage.

Guys, to get this question, first answer this question - what is socket www server (non-standard)?
ip_addr:tcp_8080, right? so traffic FROM WWW server (inbound direction for port Gi0/0)
will always have TCP 8080 port, in other words, it is reverse traffic\reply to the web clients.
of course to match this traffic we need to use this ACL:
cisco_R3(config-ext-nacl)#$cp host 192.168.0.5 eq 8080 host 172.16.0.2
cisco_R3(config-ext-nacl)#
cisco_R3(config-ext-nacl)#do s runn ip access-list extended q_266

 permit tcp any any range 22 443

On what model of switch? These questions sometimes. On a 9300 the syntax would be "source destination eq port" not "source eq port destination"

192.168.0.5 port 8080

Answer is C, as the ACL is applied INBOUND on the Web server's switch port (G0/0).

Therefore the traffic needing to be blocked will have a source IP and port of the server (192.168.0.5:8080) and a destination address of PC-1 (172.16.0.2) on any port.
